questions.question:
Question 1: A mother brought a healthy-looking, 3-month-old infant for routine immunization. As you 
were giving the shot, you noticed some noisy breathing in the baby, which became worse once 
he started crying. However, it decreased, as you held him in a prone position. There were no 
clear signs of distress. According to his mother, he had been feeding well at home and has not 
had any episodes of apnea or cyanosis. Which is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
A clinical picture of inspiratory stridor that worsens on crying and relieves in a prone position in a 
newborn without respiratory distress is suggestive of laryngomalacia. Laryngomalacia is the most common congenital laryngeal anomaly and the most common cause 
of stridor in infants and children. Stridor is exacerbated by any exertion: crying, agitation, or 
feeding. In the prone position, the stridor disappears. On laryngoscopy, an omega-shaped epiglottis is visualized. In most children, only expectant observation is required as the condition resolves secondary to 
nervous system maturation, within 18 to 24 months of birth. However, neonates with severe 
laryngomalacia may develop marked upper airway obstruction resulting in cor pulmonale, 
life-threatening apneic episodes, feeding difficulties, obstructive sleep apnea, and failure to 
thrive. In such cases, surgical resection of supraglottic tissues and supraglottoplasty has been the 
favoured approach.

questions.question:
Question 2: A senior casualty nurse informs you that a 5-year-old girl with severe respiratory distress 
might require intubation. You just finished stabilising and placing an ET tube in Mohan, a 
57-year-old man with head trauma and a GCS of 7. Which of the following is not a feature of 
child's airway?

options.a: The larynx being located higher in the neck at the level of C3-C4
options.b: The narrowest part being the subglottic region

questions.explanation:
The pediatric airway is funnel shaped. In comparison, the adult airway is cylindrical. 433 
Sold by @itachibot In newborns, the larynx is situated at the level of C3-C4, where it facilitates simultaneous 
respiration and swallowing during feeding.

questions.question:
Question 3: During a night shift, you get a call from the ER to come and see a toddler, who presented with 
complaints of fever, drooling, and a muffled voice since evening. On examination, the child 
has a stridor and you pick up a "thumb sign" on the lateral x-ray of his neck. What is the most 
likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Thumb sign on lateral x-ray of neck is pathognomonic for acute epiglottitis (AE). It is seen due to 
epiglottic enlargement. AE is an inflammation of the epiglottis. The arytenoids, false cords, and posterior tongue may also 
be involved. In children, Haemophilus influenzae type B (Hib) is the most common cause. This has decreased 
dramatically since the widespread availability of immunization (pentavalent). Streptococcus 
pyogenes, S. pneumoniae, and S. aureus have also been implicated. Non-infectious causes can be 
foreign body ingestion and trauma from thermal or caustic agents. It has a progressive and potentially fulminating course, characterised by high fever, sore throat, 
dyspnea, and rapidly progressing respiratory obstruction. AE is a clinical diagnosis and a true emergency, X-ray soft tissue neck is not necessary to confirm 
it. It may be used to rule out differentials such as laryngotracheobronchitis, foreign body 
obstruction, retropharyngeal abscess or congenital anomalies. The time taken for X-rays should be 
avoided in a critically ill child due to the risk of sudden complete airway obstruction. The definitive diagnosis of AE is made during direct laryngoscopy. However, since manipulation 
can induce a laryngospasm, it is generally avoided. The image below shows thumb sign:

questions.question:
Question 4: Which of the following is the most common etiological agent associated with epiglottitis in 
children, overall in the world?
questions.explanation:
434 
Sold by @itachibot The most common etiological agent, overall in the world, of acute epiglottitis in the pediatric age 
group, now is Streptococcus. In the past, Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib) used to be the most commonly identified cause 
of acute epiglottitis. But, since the widespread use of the H. influenzae type b vaccine, invasive 
disease caused by H. influenzae type b in pediatric patients has been reduced by 99%. Therefore, other organisms, such as Streptococcus pyogenes (GAS), Streptococcus penumoniae, 
non-typeable H. influenzae, and Staphylococcus aureus, have become the common causes of acute 
epiglottitis in pediatric age group, overall in the world. Lateral X-ray of the neck shows the thumb sign in acute epiglottitis.

questions.question:
Question 5: A 5 year old boy was suffering from low grade fever, inspiratory stridor and barking cough for 
past 5 days. His chest X-ray is given below. What is the cause of this condition?
questions.explanation:
Barking cough is a feature of laryngotracheobronchitis, which is caused by the parainfluenza 
virus. The X-ray finding is the 'Steeple sign' due to subglottic narrowing. The age of presentation of laryngotracheobronchitis ranges from 6 months-6 years. The clinical 
features include barking cough, inspiratory stridor, hoarseness, low-grade fever. Management: • Racemic epinephrine nebulization leads to the rapid improvement of upper airway obstruction. 
Epinephrine constricts pre-capillary arterioles in the upper airway mucosa and decreases capillary 
hydrostatic pressure, leading to fluid resorption and improvement in airway edema. • Dexamethasone-by the least invasive route (Oral>IV>IM ). It is indicated in all the grades 
of croup. • Oxygen should be administered to children who are hypoxemic (SpO2 <92 %) Antibiotics are not indicated in laryngotracheobronchitis.

questions.question:
Question 6: 423 
Sold by @itachibot 2-year-old Neha has been having fever since yesterday and is refusing food. Parents became 
alarmed when she developed an abnormal barking cough today morning and have brought 
her to the casualty. On examination, the child looked exhausted and had visible chest 
retractions and stridor. The temperature was 39.6 degrees and SpO2 was 93% on room air. 
Chest X-ray reveals a 'steeple' sign. What is the treatment of choice in this child?

options.c: Send a throat swab and start IV antibiotics

questions.explanation:
Fever, barking cough, inspiratory stridor and a steeple sign on chest radiograph are suggestive of 
acute laryngotracheobronchitis (croup). The treatment of choice in this child is nebulization with 
racemic epinephrine. Epinephrine acts rapidly and provides immediate relief. It constricts pre-capillary arterioles in the 
upper airway mucosa and decreases capillary hydrostatic pressure. This increases fluid resorption 
and reduces airway edema. Westley Croup Severity Score: Overall score and severity • 0 to 2- mild • 3 to 7- moderate • 8 to 11- severe 435 
Sold by @itachibot • 12 to 17- impending respiratory failure Treatment of moderate to severe croup : • Racemic epinephrine nebulization • Dexamethasone is indicated in all grades of croup and is given by the least invasive route 
(Oral>IM>IV) • Oxygen should be administered to children who are hypoxemic (SpO2 <92 %) • Antibiotics are not indicated in croup Feature

questions.question:
Question 7: A child in your unit is admitted with acute bronchiolitis. Which of the following is the most 
common etiological agent responsible for this condition during infancy?
questions.explanation:
Acute bronchiolitis is predominantly a viral disease in children younger than 2 years. Respiratory 
syncytial virus (RSV) is the most likely etiological agent and is responsible for more than 50% of 
cases. Acute bronchiolitis refers to airway inflammation and obstruction of the lower respiratory tract. Clinical features of bronchiolitis include fever, cough, fine inspiratory crackles, expiratory 
wheezes, and breathing difficulty. Cyanosis may be seen in severe cases. Radiographs may be normal in some patients. In the majority of them, there will be interstitial 
infiltrates, hyper-expansion of the chest, and peribronchial thickening. Management is mainly conservative. Hypoxemic children should receive cool, humidified oxygen. 
Rarely, a child might develop respiratory failure and require hospitalization and invasive 
ventilation.

questions.question:
Question 8: 10-month-old Ishaan was presented to the OPD with a 3-day history of lower respiratory tract 
symptoms and an expiratory wheeze. Chest X-ray showed mild peribronchial thickening. 
Which of the following statements is false regarding the condition described?

options.a: The risk is higher for infants with young mothers or mothers who smoked during pregnancy.
options.b: It is more common in children who have not been breastfed.
options.c: The mainstay of treatment is antibiotics.
options.d: There is a higher incidence of wheezing and asthma in children with a history of bronchiolitis.

questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute bronchiolitis. The treatment is mainly supportive. 
Hypoxemic children should receive cool, humidified oxygen. Rarely, a child might develop 
respiratory failure and require hospitalization and invasive ventilation. 436 
Sold by @itachibot It is more common in boys, in those who have not been breastfed, and in those who live in 
crowded conditions. The risk is higher for infants with young mothers or mothers who smoked 
during pregnancy. Acute bronchiolitis is predominantly a viral disease caused by respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) 
and antibiotics are not indicated. There is a higher incidence of wheezing and asthma in children with a history of bronchiolitis.

questions.question:
Question 9: The pediatric intensivist is contemplating whether to start aerosolized ribavirin in a young 
boy with a severe respiratory infection. There would be a clear indication to start the drug if 
 
.

options.b: The child has not received any immunization
options.c: There is a history of severe atopy
options.d: There is a history of recurrent infection

questions.explanation:
Ribavirin is the only specific antiviral therapy available for the treatment of severe bronchiolitis 
caused by RSV infections. It is reserved as a last-line agent for life-threatening bronchiolitis in 
patients who are immunocompromised or who have hemodynamically significant 
cardiopulmonary disease. In otherwise healthy children, the management of acute RSV 
bronchiolitis is typically supportive. Ribavirin is a prodrug, which when metabolized resembles purine RNA nucleotides. In this form, 
it interferes with RNA metabolism required for viral replication. MNEMONIC: (for indications of ribavirin) • C-RIBAvirin: • Hepatitis C • RSV • Influenza B • Arenaviruses (Lassa, Bolivian, etc.) Note - Ribavirin is also used in the treatment of hepatitis C and some viral hemorrhagic fevers.

questions.question:
Question 10: 3-year-old Sravya was referred with a one-week history of being unable to look upwards, 
constant neck flexion, and deviation to the right side. Parents also complained of feeding 
difficulty. On examination, the child was noted to have poor oral hygiene and the neck was 
tender on palpation. The X-ray is given below. Which of the following statements are false 
about the given condition?

options.a: It occurs mostly in children younger than 3-4 years
options.b: It is more common in boys
options.c: Examination shows unilateral bulging of the posterior pharyngeal wall
options.d: Trauma to the posterior pharynx is the most common cause

questions.explanation:
The history of progressive torticollis, neck pain and dysphagia in a young child along with a neck 
X-ray demonstrating a prevertebral soft-tissue swelling are all indicative of a retropharyngeal 
abscess. In young children, an antecedent upper respiratory tract infection is the most common 
cause of an RP abscess and not trauma. It involves the suppuration of lymph nodes present in the RP space and is more common in 
children younger than 3-4 years since these lymph node chains involute after 5 years of age. Boys 
are affected more often than girls. In older children and adults, the cause is usually trauma to the 
posterior pharynx, which leads to inoculation of the retropharyngeal space. Risk factors include poor oral hygiene, diabetes, an immunocompromised state, and low 
socioeconomic status. Clinical manifestations are nonspecific and include fever, decreased oral intake, and drooling. 
Neck stiffness and torticollis may also be present. As the abscess grows in size, it can also lead to 
upper airway obstruction and asphyxiation. The physical examination can reveal unilateral 437 
Sold by @itachibot bulging of the posterior pharyngeal wall. Although lateral radiograph is used for initial imaging, CT of the neck with intravenous contrast is 
the best imaging study to evaluate patients with a retropharyngeal abscess. Treatment ranges 
from prolonged courses of intravenous antibiotics to surgical incision and drainage.

questions.question:
Question 12: A 9-year-old boy presented with a 4-day history of high-grade fever and a productive cough 
with yellow sputum. Chest x-ray showed a consolidation in the right middle zone. According 
to WHO guidelines, which of the following is not an indication for hospital admission?
questions.explanation:
As per the revised 2014 WHO guidelines, it is safe to treat chest indrawing pneumonia at home. However, a child who is HIV positive and has chest indrawing will need to be referred for 
inpatient treatment. Only those children who have general danger signs are classified as having 
“severe pneumonia” and need to be referred to a higher level (hospital admission). Danger signs: • Not able to drink • Persistent vomiting • Convulsions • Lethargic or unconscious • Stridor in a calm child 438 
Sold by @itachibot • Severe malnutrition

questions.question:
Question 13: A 5th standard girl is brought to the OPD with a high fever and cough with expectoration for 
3 days. Her chest X-ray shows multiple pneumatoceles. Which of the following is the most 
common etiological agent implicated in this presentation?
questions.explanation:
Staphylococcus aureus pneumonia manifests as confluent bronchopneumonia, which is often 
unilateral and characterized by the presence of hemorrhagic necrosis and irregular areas of 
cavitation of the lung parenchyma, resulting in pneumatoceles, empyema, or at times, 
bronchopulmonary fistulas. The following CT image shows cavitating pneumonia by S. aureus:

Question 14: A one-and-half-year-old child brought to the hospital with a history of breathlessness, fever, 
cough, and cold. On examination, respiratory rate was 46/min, and there were no chest 
retractions. Which is the most appropriate management?

options.b: Give IV antibiotics and refer to higher centre
options.c: Oral antibiotics, warn of danger signs, and send home
options.d: No need of treatment only home remedies

questions.explanation:
439 
Sold by @itachibot The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute respiratory illness. According to the IMNCI 
guidelines 2020, this child can be classified as having 'Pneumonia'. The treatment is oral 
amoxicillin, vitamin A and home care advice. Fast breathing is defined as given in the table below: Age of chil

questions.question:
Question 15: 426 
Sold by @itachibot An adolescent boy with a family history of asthma presented with intermittent wheeze and 
cough for 2 months. The onset of wheeze is triggered during exercise and while playing at 
school. Which of the following is preferred as regular therapy for the prevention of his 
symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Inhaled corticosteroids are recommended as regular therapy for the prevention of his symptoms 
of exercise-induced asthma. According to GINA 2021 guidelines, exercise-induced bronchoconstriction can be prevented with 
daily treatment (regular therapy) with inhaled corticosteroids. SABA, LABA, or chromones may be 
used prior to exercise, along with warm-up before exercise. Those who have mild exercise-induced asthma can use their regular inhaled corticosteroid before 
exercise and need not take SABA pre-exercise.

questions.question:
Question 16: A 17-year-old boy presented to the clinic with an acute respiratory tract infection. He has a 
history of asthma associated with recurrent respiratory tract infections and sinusitis. Genetic 
testing in childhood had revealed CFTR mutations. Which of the following is likely to be 
decreased in this patient?
questions.explanation:
440 
Sold by @itachibot The given clinical scenario is suggestive of cystic fibrosis. In these patients, sperm count is most 
likely to be decreased. Male patients with cystic fibrosis usually have infertility due to failure of development of Wolffian 
duct structures leading to congenital absence of bilateral vas deferens. There is defective sperm 
transport resulting in obstructive azoospermia. The sexual function is generally unimpaired. Option A: Sweat chloride levels are elevated (60 mEq/L) due to abnormalities in the CFTR 
protein leading to defective chloride transport. Option B: Serum bicarbonate levels are increased due to excessive loss of salt in the sweat 
resulting in hypochloremic alkalosis. Option D: Patients with cystic fibrosis have fat malabsorption secondary to exocrine pancreatic 
insufficiency, hence the increased stool fat.

questions.question: Question 17: Which of the following has similar inheritance pattern as cystic fibrosis?

options.a: Accumulation of glycogen in the lysosome
options.b: Trinucleotide repeat expansion of CAG on chromosome 4

questions.explanation:
Cystic fibrosis (CF), is an autosomal-recessive disorder. Accumulation of glycogen in the lysosome 
is seen in Pompe's disease which is another autosomal-recessive disorder. Option B: Trinucleotide repeat expansion of CAG on chromosome 4 is seen in Huntington's 
disease, which is autosomal dominant. Options C and D: Adult-onset polycystic kidney disease and retinoblastoma (RB gene mutation) 
are autosomal-dominant diseases.

questions.question: Question 18: Which of the following statements about cystic fibrosis is not true?

options.b: Abnormality in CFTR gene leads to defective calcium transport.
options.c: Mutation in cystic fibrosis transport regulator is seen.
options.d: Males have infertility in adult life

questions.explanation:
In cystic fibrosis, abnormalities in the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator 
(CFTR) gene lead to defective chloride channels and not calcium channels. Cystic fibrosis (CF) is an autosomal-recessive disorder of children and adults. Dysfunction of the 
CFTR, the primary defect, leads to a wide and variable array of presenting manifestations and 
complications. The most common CFTR mutation is F508 deletion. More than 95% of males are azoospermic because of failure of development of Wolffian duct 
structures, but the sexual function is generally unimpaired.

questions.question:
Question 19: The most common organism causing pneumonia in cystic fibrosis among the pediatric age 
group is  
.
questions.explanation:
Staphylococcus aureus is the most common organism causing pneumonia in cystic fibrosis among 
the given options. The most common organisms causing pneumonia in CF patients: 441 
Sold by @itachibot • The pediatric age group- S. aureus • The adult population- P. aeruginosa (mucoid) Pseudomonas aeruginosa-mucoid may also cause pneumonia in pediatric CF patients. In cystic fibrosis, P. aeruginosa shows a special feature of developing a mucoid capsule. This 
complex polysaccharide generates a biofilm that provides a hypoxic environment and thereby 
protects Pseudomonas against antimicrobial agents. Burkholderia cepacia pneumonia is associated with higher mortality, but it is not the most 
common. These patients are found to have severe pulmonary hypertension, possibly due to 
pulmonary inflammatory vascular response.

questions.question:
Question 20: A 5-year-old boy was evaluated for cystic fibrosis. Sweat chloride shows value of 38 and 44 
mEq/L (normal<40). Which is the next best test to confirm the diagnosis of cystic fibrosis?
questions.explanation:
DNA analysis is used to confirm the diagnosis of cystic fibrosis in patients with equivocal (one 
normal and one abnormal value) or frankly normal sweat chloride values. The diagnosis is confirmed if both of the following criteria are met: • Presence of • Clinical symptoms affecting at least one organ system (respiratory, gastrointestinal, or 
genitourinary) or • Positive newborn screening or • A sibling with cystic fibrosis • Evidence of dysfunction of the CFTR gene by • Two positive sweat chloride test results obtained on separate days or • Identification of two CFTR mutations by genetic testing or • An abnormal measurement of nasal potential difference Options A and B: 72-hour fecal fat and chest CT are not used in the diagnosis of CF. Option D: This testing is primarily used in research applications and has never undergone 
extensive validation as a clinical tool.

questions.question:
Question 21: A couple planning for pregnancy visits you for genetic counseling. They are both known to be 
heterozygous carriers of CFTR mutations. Which of the following is the most likely 
complication in an affected child at birth?
questions.explanation:
CFTR mutations are associated with cystic fibrosis (CF). Meconium ileus is a common 
complication associated with CF patients at birth. Meconium found in the intestine of a neonate consists of succus entericus (bile salts, bile acids, 
and debris from the intestinal mucosa) and is normally evacuated within 6 hours of birth (or 
earlier). Meconium ileus occurs in the first 24-48 hours of life when meconium becomes inspissated and 
obstructs the distal ileum causing abdominal distension and emesis. Abdominal radiographs show 442 
Sold by @itachibot dilated loops of bowel with air-fluid levels and, frequently, a collection of granular, “ground-glass” 
material in the lower central abdomen. Meconium ileus may also be seen with pancreatic atresia or pancreatic duct stenosis. Radiological image shows contrast enema in a newborn infant with abdominal distention and 
failure to pass meconium. Several air–fluid levels in the small bowel are visible on the upright 
lateral view.

questions.question:
Question 22: A 9-year-old boy, diagnosed with cystic fibrosis shortly after birth has been having around 2-3 
exacerbations per year, requiring hospital admissions. Infection by which of the following 428 
Sold by @itachibot organisms has increased mortality in such patients?
questions.explanation:
Cystic fibrosis patients with Burkholderia cepacia pneumonia are found to have severe pulmonary 
hypertension, possibly due to pulmonary inflammatory vascular response, and have higher 
mortality. Staphylococcus aureus and Pseudomonas aeruginosa (mucoid) are the most common pathogens 
causing pneumonia in CF patients. However, they have lower mortality compared to B. cepacia.

questions.question:
Question 23: A 3-year-old boy presents with a history of recurrent pneumonia and chronic diarrhea. His 
mother states that he has 6-8 foul-smelling stools per day. Physical examination reveals a 
low-grade fever and scattered rhonchi over both lung fields. Sweat chloride testing is elevated 
on 2 separate occasions. Which of the following drugs is used as a treatment option for this 
condition?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of cystic fibrosis (CF). Ivacaftor is used in the treatment of 
cystic fibrosis. Ivacaftor is a potentiator of the chloride channel and overcomes its defect. It activates the 
CFTR-G551D mutant protein. Remember: IvaCaFToR (CFTR mutation in CF)

questions.question:
Question 24: A 4-year-old girl presented with cough and difficulty breathing following accidental inhalation 
of a peanut. On examination, there was localised wheezing and decreased breath sounds on 
the right side. What is the next best step in management?
questions.explanation:
443 
Sold by @itachibot In a child with a suspected foreign body in the lung, the next best step would be to do a rigid 
bronchoscopy as it is both diagnostic and therapeutic. The rigid bronchoscope has a ventilation mechanism and a suction port making it easy for 
visualization and handling of the foreign body. However, it is pertinent to note that the initial 
investigation is usually a chest X-ray.

questions.question:
Question 25: All the following are true about Macleod syndrome except that  
.

options.a: It is also called Swyer-James syndrome.
options.b: It is not a true emphysema.
options.c: It is mostly linked to adenovirus.
options.d: Affected lung is larger in size compared to unaffected lung.

questions.explanation:
Macleod syndrome refers to the inability of the lungs to grow after a severe obstructive 
bronchiolitis. Children with this condition often have chronic cough, recurrent pneumonia, and 
wheezing. On CT scan, the affected lung shows small size and decreased vascularity, 
hyperexpansion, and hyperlucency (false emphysema). It is also called Swyer–James syndrome. It is mostly linked to adenovirus. Patients respond well 
to bronchodilators.

questions.question:
Question 26: A 15-year-old child has been recurrently hospitalized for infections, since 2 years of age. After 
a detailed evaluation, a diagnosis of Kartagener's syndrome was suspected. All of the 
following are components of the Kartagener triad except  
.
questions.explanation:
Male infertility is typical in Kartagener syndrome, but not a component of the triad. Kartagener’s syndrome is primary ciliary dyskinesiacharacterized by the classical triad of: • Situs inversus • Chronic sinusitis • Bronchiectasis Primary ciliary dyskinesia (also called immotile cilia syndrome) is an autosomal recessive disorder 
affecting ciliary motility. It occurs due to ultrastructural defects in the dynein arm of cilia. This 
causes the retention of secretions due to a failed mucociliary clearance mechanism. Clinically, this 
manifests as chronic sinusitis and recurrent infections that ultimately lead to bronchiectasis. As ciliary function is necessary to ensure proper rotation of the developing organs in the chest and 
abdomen. Its absence, will lead to situs inversus or a partial lateralizing abnormality. Male patients with this condition tend to be infertile, due to asthenospermia (immotile 
spermatozoa due to impaired sperm flagella function).

questions.question: Question 27: All the following are components of Young's syndrome except:
questions.explanation:
Asthma is not usually seen in Young's syndrome. Young's syndrome is characterized by: • Bronchiectasis • Sinusitis 444 
Sold by @itachibot • Obstructive azoospermia In contrast, Kartagener's syndrome is characterized by • Bronchiectasis • Sinusitis • Situs inversus

questions.question:
Question 28: A term male neonate develops respiratory distress at birth, unresponsive to surfactant. 
Echocardiography is normal and chest X-ray shows a ground-glass appearance. Parents say 
that their first child died at 10 days of birth due to similar complaints. What is the most likely 
diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The history and chest X-ray findings are suggestive of pulmonary alveolar proteinosis (PAP). PAP is a rare, diffuse lung disease that is characterized by alveolar and interstitial accumulation of 
a periodic acid-Schiff (PAS) stain-positive phospholipoprotein (derived from surfactant). Infants and children with PAP present with dyspnea, fatigue, cough, weight loss, chest pain, or 
hemoptysis. Boys are affected 3 times as often as girls. Chest X-ray shows ground-glass opacity and HRCT shows crazy-paving pattern (as shown below). Treatment options include total lung lavage, inhaled or subcutaneous granulocyte-macrophage 
colony-stimulating factor (GM-CSF).

questions.question:
Question 29: 430 
Sold by @itachibot A 3-month old previously healthy baby was brought to the casualty when the parents found 
that the baby was not breathing while asleep. Following resuscitative measures, the baby was 
still apnoeic, pulseless and asystolic. Which of the following is not a risk factor for sudden 
infant death syndrome?

options.b: Infants born to women aged >35 years
options.c: Infants of mother who smoked during pregnancy

questions.explanation:
Higher maternal age is not a risk factor for sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS). Risk factors for SIDS include • Low socioeconomic status • 3-4 months of age have the highest incidence 445 
Sold by @itachibot • Higher birth order irrespective of maternal age and low birth weight • Cigarette smoking, alcohol, and drug abuse during pregnancy • Sleeping prone, even side sleeping increases the risk

questions.question:
Question 30: A 6-month-old infant was admitted because of increasing stridor since birth, cough, 
pulmonary infections, and episodes of acute respiratory distress. On detailed evaluation using 
bronchoscopy and MRI imaging, a bronchial cyst was found to be the cause. The following are 
features of the lesion except that  
.

options.b: It is usually confined to 1 lobe.
options.d: It is never associated with malignancy.

questions.explanation:
Bronchial cysts are associated with malignancy (pleuropulmonary blastoma). Bronchial cysts are congenital malformations of the bronchial tree. It mainly presents as 
a mediastinal mass that may enlarge and cause local compression. It is usually confined to a single lobe and is mostly multiloculated.

questions.question:
Question 31: In a child with yellow nail syndrome, you would expect to find all the following clinical 
features except  
.
questions.explanation:
Yellow nail syndrome is not associated with clubbing. Yellow nail syndrome is characterized by respiratory manifestation (pleural effusion, 
bronchiectasis), lymphedema, and discoloured nails. Yellow nail syndrome almost always occurs after 50 years of age, but a juvenile or familial form 
has also been observed.

questions.question: Question 32: What is the most likely cause of a mediastinal mass in a 2-year-old child?

options.b: Pressure in right and left ventricles are equal
options.c: Liver receives blood with low oxygen saturation compared to the brain
options.d: Blood in inferior venacava has lower oxygen concentration compared to superior venacava

questions.explanation:
The most common mediastinal masses in young children are neurogenic tumours (50%-60%). In 
most cases (< 4 years of age), they are invariably malignant (neuroblastomas). Anterior mediastinal masses: • Thymoma - most common • Malignant lymphoma (Hodgkin's and non-Hodgkin's) • Teratoma • Thyroid (retro- or sub-sternal extension) • Thymic cyst • Angioma Middle mediastinal masses: • Foregut duplication cyst (bronchogenic, enteric, and neurenteric) - most common • Lymphadenopathy • Vascular malformations Posterior mediastinal masses: 446 
Sold by @itachibot • Neurogenic tumour - most common overall • Foregut duplication cyst • Vascular malformations • Extramedullary hematopoiesis 447 
Sold by @itachibot Fetal Circulation
